Responding to scathing criticism, the University of Texas says it will take steps to resolve conflicts of interest related to a campus energy institute’s 2012 report on the potential effects of fracking, Andrew C. Revkin reports. The institute has been faulted for ties to the natural gas drilling industry. The university said it had accepted all of the recommendations of an independent review panel that found that the institute had shown “very poor judgment” and an “inattention” to the “challenges of conducting research in an environment inevitably fraught with conflict of interest concerns.”

Big changes at The Wine Advocate: Robert M. Parker Jr. will sell the consumer newsletter to Asian investors and step down as editor in chief. He will become chairman and continue to review Bordeaux and Rhône wines, The Wall Street Journal reports. Its headquarters will move to Singapore, and Lisa Perrotti-Brown will become top editor. The Wanxiang Group, a Chinese auto parks manufacturer, has won the bidding for A123 Systems, a bankrupt car battery maker that figured prominently in the Obama administration’s push for electric vehicles, The New York Times reports. Wanxiang will pay $256 million for all A123 assets save businesses tied to the United States government and military; a small energy company based in Illinois will claim those with a $2.2 million bid. Read more »

The Financial Times, the pink-hued chronicle of business news, may become the latest outpost of the Bloomberg L.P. media empire, as it weighs a bid for the newspaper, The New York Times reports. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has been seen carrying The Financial Times in his daily stack of reading material, and he visited the paper’s London headquarters in October. When asked if he would buy the paper, Mr. Bloomberg answered only, “I buy it every day.” Read more »

Some say India’s newly-announced cash-transfer program is “a game-changer because it will limit corruption by reducing face-to-face interactions with public officials, who often ask for a cut of the money they hand out,” Hartosh Singh Bal wrote in the International Herald Tribune. “But others claim it’s the desperate attempt of a mother, the Congress President Sonia Gandhi, to buy the election for her son, Rahul Gandhi, a middling politician at best. Cynical as that last view is, I am inclined to agree with it.”

A new genetic study suggests the ancestors of Europe’s Romany people “arrived in Europe from northwestern India in a single wave around 1,500 years ago, half a millennium earlier than previously thought,” Harvey Morris wrote in the International Herald Tribune’s Rendezvous blog. “The international authors of the peer-reviewed paper in the journal Current Biology said their study was the most comprehensive ever of the demographic history of the Romany,” he wrote. We are inviting readers to join our live college application help line on Facebook this week. Marie Bigham, a former college admissions officer and veteran college counselor at Greenhill School, a private high school in Addison, Tex., has agreed to answer your questions in real time, before the ball drops and signals the Jan. 1 deadline for most applications. The live help line will take place on Wednesday, from 8 to 9 p.m. Eastern time, on The New York Times’s main Facebook page. If you would like to get a head start, we encourage you to pose your questions in the comment box of the original post. Ms. Bigham will try to tackle as many early questions as possible during the Facebook chat on Wednesday night.

Some countries, China and Australia among them, never saw their economies decline, but most did, and some of the largest economies remain smaller than they were in 2007. The world economy — measured by total gross domestic product in 56 countries for which data are available — is now about 6 percent larger.
